commitmsg:
This change fixes 2 things
 1. Enforce "no follow" of symlinks when we open the file for download. This
    was done by monkey patching the Rack::File class to add the File::NOFOLLOW
    open flag.

 2. Add a feature that allows users to view/download symlinks that point within
    their app's subdirectory. To check whether the symlink point to the users
    file/subdir, the code makes the assumption that the first subdir under
    "root" is the apps subdirectory. e.g.
    if root is ".../blah/app" then
                 ".../bhah/app/some_app" is the apps subdirectory.
    The change converts symlinks to real path and checks if that real path begins
    with the apps subdir, if it does we allow access to that file/subdir.

Revert "This change fixes 2 things"

This reverts commit 6709b96726217cc00b07fb6aae104800f3672392.

This was checked in by accident I meant to send a pull request.

This change fixes 2 things
1. Enforce "no follow" of symlinks when we open the file for download. This
   was done by monkey patching the Rack::File class to add the File::NOFOLLOW
   open flag.

2. Add a feature that allows users to view/download symlinks that point within
their app's subdirectory. To check whether the symlink point to the users
file/subdir, the code makes the assumption that the first subdir under "root" is the
apps subdirectory. e.g.
  if root is ".../blah/app" then
             ".../bhah/app/some_app" is the apps subdirectory.
  The change converts symlinks to real path and checks if that real path begins
  with the apps subdir, if it does we allow access to that file/subdir.

Renamed README to README.rdoc and took a stab at adding a heading

Right now the README shows up in raw form on Github because there's no file
extension on it. Adding a .rdoc extension makes Github process it as RDoc
and convert it into nicely formatted HTML.

In addition I tried adding a heading taking my best guess at what "vcap"
actually stands for. The README should probably have some kind of heading
even if it's just "VCAP".

Merge "Add utility classes."

Make staging a blocking operation.

The callers of app_manager#stage were written back before
the cc was made async.  The callers assumed that the call to
the stager was a blocking operation and start making other
state modifications to the app immediately after calls
to app_manger#stage.  This leads to races and the hm usually
needs to get involved to fix things up, especially given
that vmc jumps in and restarts apps after doing a service
binding.

Change-Id: I81d96a44ed431a8b8ad661f966c0aa3156a7bf00

Fix log file truncation bug in bin/vcap

bin/vcap redirects stdout/stderr to a log file in /tmp/vcap-run if no log
file is specified in a given component config. This file is not opened in append-mode,
which causes attempts to truncate the temporary log file to fail. Fix this
by opening the file in append-mode and immediately truncating it, thus preserving the
original semantics.

Test plan:

Started vcap locally, truncated a temporary log file, made sure that the
correct size was reflected.

Change-Id: I65d55c686bed1f8d3301c91cd74ed857f3fd3aba
Merge "Chef scripts to deploy cloud foundry"

Chef scripts to deploy cloud foundry

This is part 1 of what I think will be a 3 part change. This change adds the
basic chef recipes to deploy cloudfoundry on a single host. The major change is
to install ruby1.8 and ruby1.9 into a configurable directory. As a result I
added a wrapper script to invoke vcap start that sets up the ruby paths
appropriately before starting indivdual components. Note, these changes do not
download the vcap repo (I will add that in a later change).

Most of the chef recipes were downloaded from the opscode website. Some of them
have been modified to meet our requirements.

Usage:
1.  run dev_setup/bin/vcap_dev_setup to install all the components required
by cloud foundry
2.  run dev_setup/bin/vcap_dev {start, stop, restart} to start cloud foundry
components.

Testing: Installed a base Ubuntu image, ran bvts on cloud foundry installed
using these new scripts.

Change-Id: I4c1ae68c7588efa1d1f9e44874e4c46a4e54974f

More granular dea ulimit policy

Added a configuration variable for dea to be able to control
ulimit enforcement separately from secure mode. This way even if
you don't want to run in full secure (multi-user) mode you can still
make a basic attempt to enforce application limits.

(from https://github.com/cloudfoundry/vcap/pull/63 with edits made
while pulling the change per review comments)
